'Mergenthaler Explosion'
A crowd mills around Mergenthaler Hall, after an explosion Wednesday noon. Two men were burned, one seriously, when an acetone experiment exploded.
Several fire trucks were on the scene, but the fire was extinguished immediately.

APL wants graduates eager
to accept the challenge
of responsibility
The Applied Physics Laboratory
(APL)of The Johns Hopkins University is a unique organization.
Its professional staff, including
both junior and senior members,
is allowed a measure of responsibility and initiative much greater
than in many other research and
development organizations. A
stimulating environment where
teamwork and individual initiative
are fused results in a high degree
of creativeness and professional
gratification.
For years- APL has pioneered:
the first proximity fuze, the first
supersonic ramjet engine, the missiles TERRIER, TALOS and
TARTAR. With a staff of 1275
APL technically directs the Navy's
Bumblebee guided-missile program, including the work of 21
associate and subcontractors,
among them leading universities
and industrial organizations.,

Location & Facilities:
"""Prt, •
The combined facilities of' APL
and its contractors provide staff
members with an unparalleled situation for advanced research and
development. APL's own laboratories, recently completed, encompass 350,000 sq. ft. Their locations
in suburban Washington and Baltimore, Md.allow staff members to
enjoy suburban, rural or urban
living and the manifold cultural
and recreational facilities of both
cities.
APL maintains a splendid program of staff benefits, including
financial assistance for advanced
study. Salaries compare favorably
with those of industrial organizations. For detailed information on
staff opportunities for men with
higher-than-average grades con-tact your Placement Officer or
write: Professional Staff Appointments.

Station WJHU will hold open
elections for the position of
Business Manager, as a result of
a ruling of the SAC, it was announced Tuesday.
In a meeting of the SAC last
Thursday,
Station
Manager
Frank Zampiello said, "Two
weeks agd Agronick told (former
Business Manager) Cantolino
that the books were in bad shape
... nothing had been done by
Cantolino."
As a consequence of this warning, Zampiello, Assistant Station
M,Inager Bill Babst and SAC
member Bob Boucek set up a
complete system of double entry
books, which were satisfactory to
the SAC. According to Cantolino, "The books were straightened out themselves."
At a second meeting of the
SAC, dealing with WJHU, it was
brought out that some of the
Major difficulties in which the
station finds itself are due primarily to the antiquated organization which is specified in the
WJHU constitution. iiecause of
the large influx of advertising
during the past summer, the entire Business Staff of the station, as established in the constitution, was too diversified to
handle this material efficiently,
with the resulting disorganized
accounts, it was testified.
According to Zampiello, the
Station needs a new constitution, coordinating better the
functions of the business, traffic
ana advertising Staffs.

Also discussed at last Tuesday's meeting of the SAC was
the advisability of continuing
the Central Publicity Office. SAC
Chairman Porter Claxton remarked, "The Central Publicity
Office is at present a temporary

Chairman Al Lakein expressed

"The Office will go ahead with
its plans for SAC recognition."

A Christmas party for all dorm
residents and the faculty will be
held tonight in the dorm snack
bar from 9-11 p.m. Admission
free.

A combination hillbilly music
and comedy program, given by
the "Dulaney Valley Boys," will
be presented gratis the afternoon of the 16th at 3 p.m. in
the main recreation room of the
Alumni Memorial Dormitory.

The "Boys" include JHU's
own Bruce Lloyd on bass, Bill
Mouring at the guite box, Dan
Curtis on the mandolin, Kenny
Nickovitch on the not four, but
five string banjo, Russel Hooper
strumming the stainless steel
guitar, and the strains of
Smokey Mason's fiddle.
The men from the vale introduced their country strains to
the ears of the public some seven
years ago at a local high school.
Since then the boys have enlarged, both in numbers and in
popularity, and now it may be
said that their sundry hill
screeches have traveled to the
mountains of Maryland and
southern Pennsylvania, the staid
boulevards of the nation's capitol, and the backwoods regions
of the Virginias.

"If certain nations of Latin
America gain in economic power
they can be our firmest allies"
said Johns Hopkins President
Milton Eisenhower at a dinner
honoring him last Thursday
night, where he called upon the
United States to realize the
"transcendental" importance of
Latin America to the future welfare of the world and emphasizr
that the road to a cemented elationship can be
be strengthened through better economic
co-operation.
At the banquet given by the
Baltimore Association of Commerce, Dr Eisenhpwer pointed
out that over 4aff of the port
of BaltimorOYforeign commerce
is withLatfn America, and that
total-American trade with that
area is larger than all trade with
Europe, and with the Middle
East, Far East and Oceania combined.
Rapid Expansion
Dr. Eisenhower noted that
Latin America is a rapidly expanding area. He paralleled the
present condition of the area to
that of the United States in the
early stages of its development.

Their latest popular disks are

Calling," "Sitting On Top Of The "some nations of Latin America

powerful nations in the world

will be double to the population
of the United States by the year
2000."
"Our trade will increase as
their economy increases, and the
more powerful they become the
better partners they can be for
us," he continued.
Desire For Loans
The presidential envoy to Latin America stressed that Latin
American countries desire American loans to expand their resources. "They want to know why
we can send billions of dolla-3
to Europe and to the Middle
East," he explained, "when they
cannot get private and public
loans."
Latin American countries will
have to have laws favorable "to
labor and to management and to
L'ir guarantees as to the remission of dollars if they expect to
draw our private capital," he also
said.

Engineers and scientists at Pratt & Whitney Aircraft
developed the piston engines that wrote aviation history
for three decades. Then came the jet age, and again it
was the P & W A team that came up with the mighty
J-57, most powerful production aircraft engine in the
world today. Behind such accomplishments, of course,
stand many development tools...tools like the house that
jet engines built: the Andrew Willgoos Laboratory.
Located on the eastern bank of the Connecticut River
in East Hartford, this windowless, thick concrete-walled
laboratory has been growing almost continuously since
its initial "completion" in 1950. As more powerful, far
more advanced turbojet engines are conceived, the means
for testing them in development stages must itself undergo carefully calculated alteration. Hence, authorship of
today's specifications for Willgoos Laboratory properly
belongs to the experimental engines it is testing today.
Similarly, tomorrow's proportions, capacities and equipment will depend upon the requirements of tomorrow's
power plants.
Behind the ponderous walls of this multi-million-dollar
structure lies the wherewithal to simulate many of the
rigorous flight conditions to be encountered by military
and commercial aircraft. The range of these' conditions
must vary from ambient pressures and temperatures in
a static condition at sea level all the way to the pressures, temperatures and high speeds involved in highaltitude flight.
This, then, is the house that jet engines built; at the
same time, it is the house that tomorrow's engines will
change and re-build.

Searching For An Honest Man
A young lady collided with both a policeman and this stop light on the corner of 33rd and
St. Paul Saturday evening. The stop light was last seen by Mr. Barnes' men faithfully operating
by the side of the road where it had been placed. When crews came to replace it atop its post,
the light was gone. It mysteriously appeared in front of the dorms Sunday morning. The much
travelled light has now disappeared to parts unknown, to Mr. Barnes anyway.

Responsible To The Administration Only ,
SAC Chairman Porter Claxton, in civilian clothes. The question was discussed in a recent Student Council meeting whether or not the SAC was a committee of the Student Council. Claxton

The seven-meet 1956-57 wrestling schedule has been swept
from the Hopkins athletic program. Athletic Director Marshall
Turner announced the dropping
of the mat sport in a press statement last Saturday.
Turner also announced that
the 1957-58 schedule, as well as
the Frosh program for both campaigns has been wiped from the
J.H.U. athletic slate.
Drastic Action
Lack of participation from upperclassmen has forced this
drastic action. The Frosh, who
were highly touted by all concerned, were working out when
the announcement was mad
public.
Turner decided it was in the
best interest of all concerned to
drop the sport for the time be-

ing, when the varsity squad became so depleted that there were
only eight on the team in only
six of the eight weight classes.
Dropped In '53
This is the second time in recent years that Hopkins has sent
wrestling into the doldroms of
inactivity. After the 1952-53 season, Turner canceled the sport
after the Jays finished with only
four men wrestling. However, an
informal team worked out under
Mickey Cochran, now in the
Army, and tied Gallaudet for the
Mason-Dixon Conference Tournament championship.
After this showing and the
pressure of a petition signed by
300 Hopkins men, wrestling was
revived with a four-meet schedule in 1955.
The Jays, at one time, were
the perrenial front-runners of

A Favorite Rondez Wu for Hopkins Men

the Mason-Dixon mat loop. This
sport has given the Jays more
titles and trophies than any
other, except lacrosse. The Blue
Birds captured the M-D tourney
title in 1942, 1946, 1947, 1948,
1949, 1950, plus the tie in 1954
with Gallaudet.
Last year the Jays compiled
one win and two losses in Conference competition to place
sixth in the dual meet standings. In the annual tournament,
the Birds battled to a fourth
place finish and Sam Wright
captured the heavyweight division crown.

Donald G. Sutherland graduated from Virginia Polytechnic
Institute in 1953 with an M.S.degree in chemical engineering and
an R.O.T.C. commission. He was hired by Du Pont's plant at

ES, Oran, we certainly do! We've employed quite a

Y

number of college graduates with definite military
commitments, even when we knew they could work no
more than a few weeks before reporting for duty. Take
my own case. I was hired in November of 1953 and
worked for only four weeks before leaving for the Army.
Two years later I returned to Du Pont.
You see, we're primarily interested in men on a longrange basis. The fact that they're temporarily unavailable, for a good reason like military service, isn't any bar
to their being considered for employment. After working
only one day, an employee is guaranteed full re-employment rights—that's the law. And if a man works for
Du Pont a full year before entering the service for two or
more years, he receives an extra two months' salary. If he
goes into the service for six months, he's paid a half

month's salary. When he's entitled to a vacation but
doesn't have time to take it before leaving, Du Pont
gives him equivalent pay instead.
Even if present employment is impossible, Oran, we
definitely recommend your talking with Du Pont's representatives as well as those of other companies. The very

contacts of real benefit to you when you leave military

BY AL FIGINSKI
Sports Editor

Last Saturday the Hopkins Athletic Department relayed the news to this corner that wrestling had breathed
its dying gasp on the Homewood campus; and that, for'
the next two years at least, it would remain in its newly
acquired dormant state.
•Others Prosper,
This news broke at a time when two of the other
major sports of Hopkins were planning or beginqing successful ventures in the, sporting world. The basketball
squad was opening its 1956-'57 campaign by crushing
Swarthmore and plans-were being formulated for lacrosse
trips to Florida and England.
Why did wrestling reach its present lowly state, at
a time when other sports were becoming "fat" with
prosperity? Some say that the mat sport was never given
a fair chance to grow since its reincarnation in 1953.
Others point to the tough grind that a wrestler must face.
However, the Hopkins mat conditioning program was
much lighter than that of the major wrestling powers.
Pleases No One

Whatever the reasons, the solution seems to have
pleased no one. The wrestlers feel that they have received
a "raw deal," while the administration was forced to air
its dirty laundry on the clothes line of public opinion.

The Applied Physics Laboratory
(APL)of The Johns Hopkins University is a unique organization.
Its professional staff, including
both junior and senior members,
is allowed a measure of responsibility and initiative much greater
than in many other research and
development organizations. A
stimulating environment where
teamwork and individual initiative
are fused results in a high degree
of creativeness and professional
gratification.
For years- APL has pioneered:
the first proximity fuze, the first
supersonic ramjet engine, the missiles TERRIER, TALOS and
TARTAR. With a staff of 1275
APL technically directs the Navy's
Bumblebee guided-missile program, including the work of 21
associate and subcontractors,
among them leading universities
and industrial organizations.,

Location & Facilities:
"""Prt, •
The combined facilities of' APL
and its contractors provide staff
members with an unparalleled situation for advanced research and
development. APL's own laboratories, recently completed, encompass 350,000 sq. ft. Their locations
in suburban Washington and Baltimore, Md.allow staff members to
enjoy suburban, rural or urban
living and the manifold cultural
and recreational facilities of both
cities.
APL maintains a splendid program of staff benefits, including
financial assistance for advanced
study. Salaries compare favorably
with those of industrial organizations. For detailed information on
staff opportunities for men with
higher-than-average grades con-tact your Placement Officer or
write: Professional Staff Appointments.

A combination hillbilly music
and comedy program, given by
the "Dulaney Valley Boys," will
be presented gratis the afternoon of the 16th at 3 p.m. in
the main recreation room of the
Alumni Memorial Dormitory.

The "Boys" include JHU's
own Bruce Lloyd on bass, Bill
Mouring at the guite box, Dan
Curtis on the mandolin, Kenny
Nickovitch on the not four, but
five string banjo, Russel Hooper
strumming the stainless steel
guitar, and the strains of
Smokey Mason's fiddle.
The men from the vale introduced their country strains to
the ears of the public some seven
years ago at a local high school.
Since then the boys have enlarged, both in numbers and in
popularity, and now it may be
said that their sundry hill
screeches have traveled to the
mountains of Maryland and
southern Pennsylvania, the staid
boulevards of the nation's capitol, and the backwoods regions
of the Virginias.

Engineers and scientists at Pratt & Whitney Aircraft
developed the piston engines that wrote aviation history
for three decades. Then came the jet age, and again it
was the P & W A team that came up with the mighty
J-57, most powerful production aircraft engine in the
world today. Behind such accomplishments, of course,
stand many development tools...tools like the house that
jet engines built: the Andrew Willgoos Laboratory.
Located on the eastern bank of the Connecticut River
in East Hartford, this windowless, thick concrete-walled
laboratory has been growing almost continuously since
its initial "completion" in 1950. As more powerful, far
more advanced turbojet engines are conceived, the means
for testing them in development stages must itself undergo carefully calculated alteration. Hence, authorship of
today's specifications for Willgoos Laboratory properly
belongs to the experimental engines it is testing today.
Similarly, tomorrow's proportions, capacities and equipment will depend upon the requirements of tomorrow's
power plants.
Behind the ponderous walls of this multi-million-dollar
structure lies the wherewithal to simulate many of the
rigorous flight conditions to be encountered by military
and commercial aircraft. The range of these' conditions
must vary from ambient pressures and temperatures in
a static condition at sea level all the way to the pressures, temperatures and high speeds involved in highaltitude flight.
This, then, is the house that jet engines built; at the
same time, it is the house that tomorrow's engines will
change and re-build.

The seven-meet 1956-57 wrestling schedule has been swept
from the Hopkins athletic program. Athletic Director Marshall
Turner announced the dropping
of the mat sport in a press statement last Saturday.
Turner also announced that
the 1957-58 schedule, as well as
the Frosh program for both campaigns has been wiped from the
J.H.U. athletic slate.
Drastic Action
Lack of participation from upperclassmen has forced this
drastic action. The Frosh, who
were highly touted by all concerned, were working out when
the announcement was mad
public.
Turner decided it was in the
best interest of all concerned to
drop the sport for the time be-

ing, when the varsity squad became so depleted that there were
only eight on the team in only
six of the eight weight classes.
Dropped In '53
This is the second time in recent years that Hopkins has sent
wrestling into the doldroms of
inactivity. After the 1952-53 season, Turner canceled the sport
after the Jays finished with only
four men wrestling. However, an
informal team worked out under
Mickey Cochran, now in the
Army, and tied Gallaudet for the
Mason-Dixon Conference Tournament championship.
After this showing and the
pressure of a petition signed by
300 Hopkins men, wrestling was
revived with a four-meet schedule in 1955.
The Jays, at one time, were
the perrenial front-runners of

A Favorite Rondez Wu for Hopkins Men

the Mason-Dixon mat loop. This
sport has given the Jays more
titles and trophies than any
other, except lacrosse. The Blue
Birds captured the M-D tourney
title in 1942, 1946, 1947, 1948,
1949, 1950, plus the tie in 1954
with Gallaudet.
Last year the Jays compiled
one win and two losses in Conference competition to place
sixth in the dual meet standings. In the annual tournament,
the Birds battled to a fourth
place finish and Sam Wright
captured the heavyweight division crown.

Donald G. Sutherland graduated from Virginia Polytechnic
Institute in 1953 with an M.S.degree in chemical engineering and
an R.O.T.C. commission. He was hired by Du Pont's plant at
Victoria, Texas. After two years in the service, Don returned to
his career in engineering,and is now doing plant-assistance work
in the technical section at Victoria.

ES, Oran, we certainly do! We've employed quite a

Y

number of college graduates with definite military
commitments, even when we knew they could work no
more than a few weeks before reporting for duty. Take
my own case. I was hired in November of 1953 and
worked for only four weeks before leaving for the Army.
Two years later I returned to Du Pont.
You see, we're primarily interested in men on a longrange basis. The fact that they're temporarily unavailable, for a good reason like military service, isn't any bar
to their being considered for employment. After working
only one day, an employee is guaranteed full re-employment rights—that's the law. And if a man works for
Du Pont a full year before entering the service for two or
more years, he receives an extra two months' salary. If he
goes into the service for six months, he's paid a half

month's salary. When he's entitled to a vacation but
doesn't have time to take it before leaving, Du Pont
gives him equivalent pay instead.
Even if present employment is impossible, Oran, we
definitely recommend your talking with Du Pont's representatives as well as those of other companies. The very
least you'll gain will be valuable background and some
contacts of real benefit to you when you leave military
service.

BY AL FIGINSKI
Sports Editor

Last Saturday the Hopkins Athletic Department relayed the news to this corner that wrestling had breathed
its dying gasp on the Homewood campus; and that, for'
the next two years at least, it would remain in its newly
acquired dormant state.
•Others Prosper,
This news broke at a time when two of the other
major sports of Hopkins were planning or beginqing successful ventures in the, sporting world. The basketball
squad was opening its 1956-'57 campaign by crushing
Swarthmore and plans-were being formulated for lacrosse
trips to Florida and England.
Why did wrestling reach its present lowly state, at
a time when other sports were becoming "fat" with
prosperity? Some say that the mat sport was never given
a fair chance to grow since its reincarnation in 1953.
Others point to the tough grind that a wrestler must face.
However, the Hopkins mat conditioning program was
much lighter than that of the major wrestling powers.
Pleases No One

Whatever the reasons, the solution seems to have
pleased no one. The wrestlers feel that they have received
a "raw deal," while the administration was forced to air
its dirty laundry on the clothes line of public opinion.
